The Zfh family of zinc finger / homeodomain proteins was first identified in Drosophila where it is required for differentiation of tissues such as the central nervous system and muscle .
<extra_id_0> ZEB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , a vertebrate homolog of Zfh-1 , binds a subset of E boxes and blocks myogenesis through transcriptional repression of muscle genes .
We present evidence here that <extra_id_0> ZEB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> also has an important role in controlling hematopoietic gene transcription .
Two families of transcription factors that are required for normal hematopoiesis are <extra_id_0> c-Myb <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and Ets .
These factors act synergistically to activate transcription , and this synergy is required for transcription of at least several important hematopoietic genes .

<extra_id_0> ZEB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> blocks the activity of <extra_id_0> c-Myb <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and Ets individually , but together the factors synergize to resist this repression .

text: Such repression imposes a requirement for both <extra_id_0> c-Myb <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and Ets for transcriptional activity , providing one explanation for why synergy between these factors is important .

The balance between repression by <extra_id_0> ZEB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and transcriptional activation by <extra_id_0> c-Myb <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / Ets provides a flexible regulatory mechanism for controlling gene expression in hematopoietic cells .

We demonstrate that one target of this positive/negative regulation in vivo is the <extra_id_0> alpha4 integrin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which play a key role in normal hematopoiesis and function of mature leukocytes .
